What's left of the area's rural heritage will be celebrated today at the 18th annual Long Island Fall Harvest Festival on the Riverhead campus of Suffolk Community College. From 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. there will be live music and other entertainment, line dancing, crafts and food sales, wine tastings, pony and hay rides, educational and interactive exhibitions, farm animals on display and, of course, a farmers' market with the Island's fruits, vegetables and fish. The festival is sponsored by the Long Island Farm Bureau, the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County and the college. (631) 727-7850.

Celebrating the Season

Saturday will bring four more seasonal festivals.. The 10th annual Maritime Festival is scheduled in Greenport from noon to 5 p.m. with visiting ships, sailing tours, maritime arts and crafts for children, a street fair, art show, and kayak rescue demonstrations. The activities will be repeated from noon to 5 p.m. next Sunday. (631) 765-1766.

The emphasis will be on growing things at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum Horticultural Society's Fall Flower and Harvest Show in Oakdale from noon to 4 p.m. and again from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. next Sunday. On Saturday, Bill Fix will talk about wild creatures at 1 p.m., and at 3 p.m. mushrooms will be Brian Feil's topic. Master gardeners will be on hand to answer questions. (631) 581-1002.

In Seaford at the Tackapausha Museum and Preserve, the South Shore Audubon Society will hold its second annual Fall Bird Day with slide shows, speakers and children's arts and crafts from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Morning and afternoon bird-watching field trips to local preserves are also planned. (516) 571-7443.

In Wading River at Wildwood State Park, the Fall Festival will take place from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday and next Sunday, with pie-eating contests, tractor rides, a petting zoo, face painting and a crafts fair. (631) 929-4314.
'Fall Colorscape'

At Brookhaven National Laboratory on Floyd Parkway in Upton, a Fall Colorscape, scheduled Thursday through Saturday, will feature professional artists and writers from the Suffolk Branch of the National League of American Penwomen. The programs in Berkner Hall will include a poetry workshop at 12:15 on Thursday and a watercolor workshop at noon Friday. Artworks will be displayed all three days in Brookhaven Center. (631) 344-2345.
From Weill to the Baroque

Three music series will resume this week. On Tuesday, the Joseph G. Astman International Concert Series will get under way at Hofstra University with ''Celebrating the Kurt Weill Centenary.'' The soloist will be Tammy Hensrud-Kerian, mezzo-soprano, accompanied by Mason G. Senft, piano, at 8 p.m. at the Monroe Lecture Center on the Hofstra campus in Hempstead. (516) 463-5669.

On Saturday, the Long Island Baroque Ensemble will begin ''A Baroque Feast,'' its 31st season, with ''Trumpets a la Baroque,'' the first of six different programs performed on period instruments. Carl Albach will be the trumpet soloist at 8 p.m. at St. Andrew's Lutheran Church on Brookside Drive in Smithtown. The concert will be repeated at 3 p.m. next Sunday at Christ Episcopal Church on East Main Street in Oyster Bay. (631) 724-7386.
The Waldorf Chamber Players will present their first program in their ''Evening of Music Among Friends'' series at 8 p.m. at the Waldorf School on Cambridge Avenue in Garden City. (516) 742-3434.
'Celtic Rock'

Geography can be deceiving. Take Seven Nations, for example. The five members of this pop group are from Florida. But that doesn't stop them from producing what they call ''Celtic rock.'' While committed to Scottish roots, the quintet, complete with bagpipes and fiddle, plays American pop and rock, producing a hybrid sound that fuses the two genres. Seven Nations will make its Long Island debut on Friday at 8:30 p.m. at the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center on Main Street. (631) 288-1500.
A Singing Nun

In another musical event that defies stereotypes, Sister Mary Beata Gerrity, will come to Our Lady of the Hamptons Regional Catholic School on North Main Street in Southampton for an Irish Festival at 7 p.m. Saturday and 2 p.m. next Sunday. Sister Mary, a member of the Community of the Sisters of Mercy, based in Rockville Centre, has been a professional performer for some 20 years. She will be joined by her band, the Reflections, and performers from the Mulvihill Lynch School of Irish Dance in Centereach. (631) 283-9140.
Talk Shows

Among the lectures that dot the schedule this week, two stand out. Tomorrow, Rex Reed, the film critic and raconteur, will talk with Shirley Romaine, the host of Cablevision's ''Art Scene on Long Island,'' about his life in show business and what's hot and what's not among the fall movies at 7:30 p.m. at the Cinema Arts Center on Park Avenue in Huntington. (631) 423-7610.

On Thursday, Dr. Phyllis Tortora, a retired professor of costumes and textiles at Queens College, will discuss''Underwear of Yesteryear,'' using slides and vintage designs from the Huntington Historical Society's extensive collection to make her points. Her talk will be at 7:30 p.m. at the Conklin Farmhouse Museum on High Street in Huntington. (631) 427-7045.
'Family Fun Day'

Today at 5 p.m., a concert by Tom Paxton, the folk singer, will conclude what's billed as Family Fun Day at Old Westbury Gardens Children's activities including face painting, bubble blowing and an old-fashioned hay toss, will begin at 3 p.m. In case this isn't enough for one day, the gardens will also be the host for a BMW, Ferrari and Porsche car show from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (516) 333-0048.

Free Choices TODAY Library concerts are back after a summer hiatus. At the Freeport Library, Annette Aguilar and the Stringbeans will play Latin, reggae and rock at 2:30 p.m. (516) 379-3274. Mary Mercurio will offer a program of original and inspirational music at 2 p.m. at the Long Beach Library (516) 432-7201. And Mary Phillips, mezzo-soprano, will sing Mahler, Verdi and Villa-Lobos in a concert, sponsored by the Port Washington Library, at 3 p.m. at the Landmark on Main Street. (516) 883-4400. TOMORROW Richard Hamm, a history professor at the State University at Albany, will present ''The Prosecutor and the Showgirl: A New York Story,'' a discussion of the Harry Thaw-Stanford White-Evelyn Nesbitt scandal, at a meeting of the Three Village Historical Society at 7:30 p.m. at Neighborhood House on Main Street in Setauket. (631) 751-3730.

TUESDAY The Hillwood Art Museum on the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University in Brookville is beginning a weekly series of Tuesday art lectures, which will continue through Oct. 17. For the first lecture, Peter Moriarity, a member of the Post art department faculty, will talk about important photographs of the 20th century at 7 p.m. at the museum in Hillwood Commons. (516) 299-4073.

THURSDAY Hallie Ephron, the fourth of the writing Ephron sisters (Nora, Delia and Amy), and A. A. Greeley, a psychologist, have produced a mystery novel called ''Amnesia,'' published under the pen name of G. H. Ephron. She will be at Barnes & Noble on Northern Boulevard in Manhasset at 8 p.m. to plug the book. (516) 365-6723.

FRIDAY Speaking of mystery novels -- and celebrities -- Kinky Friedman will be at the Book Revue on New York Avenue in Huntington to discuss his latest, ''Mile High Club,'' at 8 p.m. (631) 271-1442. Not by coincidence, Mr. Friedman will give a concert on Saturday at the Stephen Talkhouse in Amagansett. But that appearance isn't free. (631) 267-3117.

SATURDAY ''Memories of Jewish Lithuania,'' two groups of photographs -- one taken by George Birman in Lithuana before, during and after World War II, and the second from Antanis Sutkus's album of survivors of the Kaunas (Kovno) ghetto -- can be seen through Oct. 22 at the Great Neck Library on Bayview Avenue. An opening reception is scheduled from 6 to 8 p.m. (516) 466-8055.
